title: CV
text:
I studied maths and physics, completing my PhD in mathematics in 2015. Since then I have been working in various data science and science roles. I have led over 15 data science projects in business, government and academia, with a recent focus on clinical data science.
My current projects involve application of machine learning and statistical techniques to linked primary care data for cancer research. This is a complex area in terms of the data and domain knowledge required, and also involves a fair amount of bureaucratic wrangling (definitely the less fun part of the job).
My technical expertise ranges from data cleaning and wrangling (Pandas, Polars, DuckDB, Arrow), to machine learning model development (Pytorch, Keras), data visualisation (seaborn, ggplot), deployment (Azure) and, recently, fine-tuning LLMs for faciliating data science workflows.
A large part of my current role and previous role involves communicating and translating between domains, for example working with clinicians to refine ideas so that they can be translated into data science problems. This is challenging but also rewarding and a good source of ideas for data science applications.

text:
I am a data scientist and researcher with a PhD in mathematics. The current focus of my work is the application of statistical and machine learning methods, primarily natural language processing, to cancer research.
I have been working in data science and science roles for the past 8 years, working with time-series data, geospatial data, images, electronic health records and text.

title: Projects
text:
I enjoy the breadth and challenges of data science problems. Here are some projects I have been working on recently.


Large Language Models (LLMs) offer the potential to streamline many data science tasks including data cleaning and data transformations, information extraction and analysis. However, clinical data is highly specialised, making off-the-shelf LLMs unsuitable. Sensitivity and privacy concerns also mean that sending data to external LLM providers is prohibited. In this project I am fine-tuning open source LLMs using data that is specific to the primary care setting. These tools dramatically improve the efficiency of time-consuming tasks in clinical data science, while ensuring privacy and techical requirements are met.



Machine learning models are known to exhibit biases. This project involved developing tools for assessing and mitigating against bias in a disease surveillance platform that uses live data from hospital emergency departments.



Early detection of cancer is an important factor in reducing mortality, however many patients who are later diagnosed with cancer first present with so-called non-specific symptoms which are a challenge in clinical decision making. This project involved the development of machine learning models to identify non-specific symptoms in patients’ electronic health records, and implementing the resulting algorithms into a clinical decision support tool that is currently being trialled.



Part of my work has involved helping to develop linked data infrastructure to support research into cancer services. This requires linkage between data from primary care, hospitals and cancer registries and is challenging as much for the technical as the bureaucratic components. Ultimately this allows for a more complete picture of patients’ interactions with the health system. You can find the paper here: Data Resource Profile: Victorian Comprehensive Cancer Centre Data Connect, A Lee, D McCarthy, R Bergin, et al., International Journal of Epidemiology, 2023

title: About me
text:
I am a data scientist and researcher with a background in mathematics and physics. I have been working in data science and science roles for the past 8 years, working with time-series data, geospatial data, images, electronic health records and language (often from specialised domains such as medicine).
Recently I’ve discovered DuckDB and Polars, and, like most people, have been experimenting with Large Language Models for automating some of the drugery in data science work.
My overall philosophy for problem solving is to opt for simple techniques first and understand them well, only drawing on sophisticated tools and algorithms when needed (and sometimes out of curiosity). I like to keep up-to-state with developments in the field. Outside of work I enjoy riding my bike, languages, cooking, music and reading.
